text: Patient: Okay Doctor: You will actually set off most sensors even though if you spilled it, which you don’t want to spill fifteen thousand on the floor but oops if you’re butterfingers and it goes ping all you have to do to stop the radiation spread is actually put a piece of paper over it and the way the rays, they don’t, it’s not like, it’s not what we call a beta emitter where it just goes crazy and everybody has to run, duck, and cover and take a little tick, tick, tick, you don’t have to do that. It covers it and it’s gone. But, the TSA sensors are so sensitive that it’s even below the threshold of what the radium is. So, they do give you a card kind of like when you get a bone scan, Patient: um humm. Doctor: you know, they’re like oh, I just had a bone scan, they’ll be a similar card, but just make sure you travel with that because you’ll set it off. You know, within like a week after you get it, it should be fine Patient: Okay Doctor: but that’s important to know. I’ll just give you my funny story because my patient when we first started, he was like number one or two and no one was travelling, right, he was like no, I’m not gonna travel. So, now I’m at home and it’s Sunday night and all the sudden my cellphone rings but it’s like nine p.m. and I’m like boy, that’s odd, who would be calling me. Not a number I recognize so I was like uh, do I pick it up, it’s probably a telemarketer, ah, okay. So, I picked it up and it was some guy he was is this Dr. H____? I’m like well, it depends, who wants to know. Patient: Yeah, who wants to Doctor: He was like well, um, I have a person here who claims to be your patient. I’m like I don’t know where here is, right, but his name is blah, blah, blah. So, the thing is that particular patient we’re always joking around so I’m like is this guy punking me at nine p.m. at night and I was about just this close to going nope, never heard of him, right, but somewhere in the recesses of my mind I’m like maybe this sounds more serious. I go yes and he goes okay, well, anyways we’re at the border patrol. Patient: Oh, wow. Doctor: He set off the sensors. They went on full lock down, like everything, Patient: Oh, geez Doctor: like guns drawn because they thought he was like transporting plutonium or something.

text: Patient: All of it. Doctor: And, so you didn’t get any kind of call from the company that did the test? Patient: No. Doctor: As far as you know? Patient: No. Doctor: Oh okay. Patient: The only e-mail that I got was a confirmation that they had received my test. Family Member: But that was the only thing, right? Not that that’s a small thing, but that was – there was no other genetic, uh, information. Doctor: Actually, I gave you the wrong information. I’m sorry. So, it’s actually a higher chance that they inherit it because it’s --- I, I forgot this is what’s called – so there’s two kinds of mutations; dominant and recessive. So, recessive means you have to, uh, uh, get, uh, two bad copies to – I want to say it’s a twenty-five percent chance because you have to get two bad copies. But, in this case, if you get one bad copy, you are at risk even though you have one good copy. So, in that case, it sort of takes out your, the mother. So, they, they have a fifty percent chance of getting this gene from you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, uh, so if they get it, they’re at risk, and if they don’t get it – so, it’s a fifty-fifty as opposed to a recessive where they have a fifty percent chance from you and a fifty percent chance from the mother, and they have to get two copies to have a problem. Patient: Okay. But –

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
